verdict.summary: ArgumentException and ArgumentNullException are thrown when a method receives an invalid or null argument. Typically caused by missing DI registrations, incorrect configuration, or caller bugs. Fix by validating inputs and ensuring proper service registration.

dead_ends.action: Passing empty strings or placeholder values to bypass argument validation
dead_ends.why_fails: The method expects meaningful values; passing empty or dummy values causes logic errors or silent data corruption downstream

dead_ends.action: Removing argument validation from the method to suppress the exception
dead_ends.why_fails: Removes a safety net that prevents invalid data from entering the system; the invalid argument will cause harder-to-debug errors deeper in the call stack

workarounds.action: Trace the null or invalid argument back to its source and fix the caller
workarounds.how: Read the exception message for the parameter name, then trace the call stack to find where the invalid value originates. Fix the upstream code that produces the null or invalid value, or add proper DI registration if the argument comes from dependency injection

workarounds.action: Register missing services in the DI container
workarounds.how: If the ArgumentNullException occurs in a constructor injected by DI, check Program.cs or Startup.cs for missing service registrations. Add builder.Services.AddScoped<IMyService, MyService>() or equivalent registration

leads_to.condition: when the null argument is silently accepted without validation and used later
when invalid argument puts object into bad state for subsequent operations

preceded_by.condition: when a null reference is passed as an argument to a validating method
when missing packages cause unresolved dependencies leading to null injections

frequently_confused_with.distinction: ArgumentNullException is explicitly thrown by validation code to reject null inputs; NullReferenceException is an unhandled dereference of a null value that was not caught by validation
